<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 300, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 278, 904, 333]]<|/det|>
0625/41October/November 20181 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 522, 90]]<|/det|>
A train of mass \(5.6 \times 10^{5} \text{kg}\) is at rest in a station.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 805, 120]]<|/det|>
At time \(t = 0 \text{s}\) , a resultant force acts on the train and it starts to accelerate forwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 645, 151]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 is the distance-time graph for the train for the first 120 s.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 371, 536, 390]]<|/det|> # Fig. 11.1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 403, 918, 437]]<|/det|> Carbon-14 is a radioactive isotope with a nucleon number of 14. It decays by emitting \(\beta\) -particles. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 450, 873, 467]]<|/det|> Use any data you need from Fig. 11.1 to write down the nuclide equation for this decay. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|> A radioactive sample is placed close to a detector. The radioactive isotope in the sample has a long half-life. The detector records a count rate of 597 counts/s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 918, 152]]<|/det|> Fig. 11.2 shows the readings when different materials are placed between the radioactive sample and the detector. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 165, 712, 281]]<|/det|>
materialcount rate counts/s
a sheet of paper602
a piece of thin aluminium598
a piece of thin lead510
